com.analog.lyric.dimple.environment

Class DimpleEnvironment

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.analog.lyric.options.AbstractOptionHolder
      • com.analog.lyric.options.LocalOptionHolder
        • com.analog.lyric.dimple.options.DimpleOptionHolder
          • com.analog.lyric.dimple.environment.DimpleEnvironment
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    IDimpleEnvironmentHolder, IDimpleEventSource, IOptionHolder

    @ThreadSafe
public class DimpleEnvironment
extends DimpleOptionHolder
    Shared environment for Dimple

    Overview

    This object holds shared state for a Dimple session. Typically there will only be one instance of this class that is global across all threads, but it is possible to configure different instances in different threads in the rare case where multiple segregated Dimple sessions need to be run at the same time.

    Accessing the environment

    When working with an object that implements the IDimpleEnvironmentHolder interface, which includes both model and solver factor graph, variable and factor objects, you can reference the appropriate environment through its IDimpleEnvironmentHolder.getEnvironment() method. Root FactorGraph objects store a pointer to the active environment when they are constructed, and children of a graph will return the environment of the root graph. If the environment is not otherwise available, you can access the active environment for the current thread using the static active() method.

    Options

    The environment is the root of the option hierarchy for Dimple. It implements the IOptionHolder interface, and you can set options on it that will be inherited by all graphs that share that environment. You can use this to set default option values without having to explicitly set them on newly created graphs. For instance, in order to enable multi-threading for all graphs, you could simply write: 
     DimpleEnvironment env = DimpleEnvironment.active();
 env.setOption(SolverOptions.enableMultithreading, true);
    Any options that are set on the graph objects will override the values set on the environment.

    For more details options see the com.analog.lyric.options and com.analog.lyric.dimple.options packages as well as the Dimple User Manual.

    Event handling

    Likewise, the environment is also the root of the event source hierarchy for Dimple and holds the instance of the DimpleEventListener responsible for dispatching events. Event handling is activated by creating an event listener on the environment and registering it to dispatch specified events to designated handlers. For instance, the following code gets the listener for the environment, creating if necessary, and registers a handler for variable creation events on the given graph: 
     env.createEventListener().register(handler, VariableAddEvent.class, factorGraph);
    For more details on events, see the com.analog.lyric.dimple.events package and the Dimple User Manual.

    Logging

    The environment also provides a simple logging interface that may be used by Dimple solver implementations to log various non-fatal conditions. Although intended primarily for use in implementations of solvers and custom factors, it is also available for use by by users of Dimple. The environment provides an instance of the standard Java Logger class that is created using Logger.getLogger(java.lang.String) with the string "com.analog.lyric.dimple". This may be configured using Java system properties and config files as described in the Java LogManager class documentation; relevant properties are documented in the various handler classes (e.g. ConsoleHandler, FileHandler). The default configuration usually will just log to System.err.

    This class provides some simple methods for logging errors and warnings. The environment's logger() instance can be used directly for cases when these methods are not sufficient.

    • Method Detail

      • defaultEnvironment

        public static DimpleEnvironment defaultEnvironment()
        The default global instance of the dimple environment.

        This is used as the initial value of the active() environment for newly created threads that are not DimpleThreads. Most users should use active() instead of this.

        Since:
        0.07
        See Also:
        setDefaultEnvironment(DimpleEnvironment)

      • active

        public static DimpleEnvironment active()
        The active instance of the dimple environment.

        This is initialized to the defaultEnvironment() the first time this is invoked, but can be overridden on a per-thread baseis. Users should remember that modifications to this environment will affect other threads unless the environment has been set to a value unique to the current thread.

        Since:
        0.07
        See Also:
        setActive(DimpleEnvironment)

      • setDefaultEnvironment

        public static void setDefaultEnvironment(DimpleEnvironment env)
        Sets the default dimple environment to a new instance.
        Parameters:
        env - is a non-null environment instance.
        Since:
        0.07
        See Also:
        defaultEnvironment()

      • setActive

        public static void setActive(DimpleEnvironment env)
        Sets the active dimple environment to a new instance for the current thread.

        This sets the value of active() for the current thread only.

        Parameters:
        env - is a non-null environment instance.
        Since:
        0.07

      • setEventListener

        public void setEventListener(@Nullable
                    DimpleEventListener listener)
        Sets event listener to specified value.

        If you just want to force creation of a default listener instance, then use createEventListener() instead.

        This will invoke notify all event sources registered in the previous and new listeners that the listener has changed by invoking their IDimpleEventSource.notifyListenerChanged() methods.

        Parameters:
        listener -
        Since:
        0.07
        See Also:
        getEventListener(), createEventListener()

      • getEventParent

        @Nullable
public IDimpleEventSource getEventParent()
        Description copied from interface: IDimpleEventSource
        The parent of this object in the event hierarchy or null if at root.

        Unless otherwise noted, this will always have the same value as IOptionHolder.getOptionParent().

      • getEventSourceName

        public java.lang.String getEventSourceName()
        Name of source for use in DimpleEvent.

        This implementation returns the string "DimpleEnvironment".

      • getModelEventSource

        @Nullable
public IModelEventSource getModelEventSource()
        Description copied from interface: IDimpleEventSource
        The model object that is most closely associated with the source.

        If this object is itself a IModelEventSource this method should simply return this object.

      • notifyListenerChanged

        public void notifyListenerChanged()
        Notify the source that it should refresh its event setting.

        This can be used when the event listener settings affecting this object have changed dynamically and you want the changes to take effect earlier than would be the case automatically. For instance, objects that can generate high-frequency events may normally refresh their settings during the initialization phase.

        Currently this method does not do anything on DimpleEnvironment.

      • loadedFromMATLAB

        public static boolean loadedFromMATLAB()
        Indicates whether Dimple is being run from MATLAB.

        This returns true if the ClassLoader class used to load this class has a name beginning with "com.mathworks".

        Since:
        0.07

        This is obtained by invoking Logger.getLogger("com.analog.lyric.dimple").

        Since:

      • logWarning

        public static void logWarning(java.lang.String format,

        Logs a warning message using the thread-specific Dimple logger.

        This is simply shorthand for:

        local().logger().warning(String.format(format, args));

        Parameters:

        args - zero or more format arguments.

      • logger

        public java.util.logging.Logger logger()
        The environment-specific logger instance.

        By default this is set to getDefaultLogger() when the environment is initialized.

        Logging is typically configured using Java system properties, which is described in the documentation for LogManager. You can also configure the logger object directly.

        Since:
        0.07
        See Also:
        setLogger(java.util.logging.Logger), logWarning(java.lang.String, java.lang.Object...), logError(java.lang.String, java.lang.Object...), Logger, LogManager

      • setLogger

        public java.util.logging.Logger setLogger(java.util.logging.Logger logger)
        Sets the environment-specific logger() instance.

        This can be used to replace the logger with special implementation for test purposes when testing logging behavior.

        Parameters:
        logger -
        Returns:
        the previous logger instance.
        Since:
        0.07
